name: Pass Task 1.1 - Hello World
description: As a first step, create the classic 'Hello World' program. This will help ensure that you have all of the software installed correctly, and are ready to move on with creating other,,, programs.

name: Pass Task 1.2 - Picture Drawing
description: Create a program that calls procedures to draw a picture to a window (something other than a house which we use as the example).

name: Pass Task 1.3 - Creating a Procedure
description: Now that you have created a program that uses procedures, you can learn how to create your own procedures. Creating procedures will allow you to group your program's actions into procedures that perform meaningful tasks.

name: Credit Task 1.4 - Concept Map
description: A concept map visually shows the relationships between concepts. This task aims to help you think through the various relationships between the structured procedural programming concepts and the associated programming artefacts.

name: Pass Task 2.1 - Hand Execute Assignment
description: Using the assignment statement, you can assign a value to a variable. In this task you will demonstrate how this action works within the computer.

name: Pass Task 2.2 - Hello User
description: Now that we have variables we can create a program that reads in the users name from the Terminal and echoes back a welcome message.

name: Pass Task 2.3 - My Drawing Procedure
description: Procedures are a great way of encapsulating the instructions needed to perform a task. In most cases the task will need some input data for it to work with. Use parameters to provide data to your procedures.

name: Pass Task 2.4 - My Functions
description: Using functions you can now create artefacts to encapsulate the steps needed to calculate a value.

name: Credit Task 2.5 - Concept Maps
description: A concept map visually shows the relationships between concepts. This task aims to help you think through the various relationships between the structured procedural programming concepts and the associated programming artefacts.

name: Pass Task 3.1 - Hand Execution of Control Flow
description: In this task you will use the hand execution process to demonstrate how the control flow constructs operate within the computer.

name: Pass Task 3.2 - Name Tester
description: Control flow enables you to easily add conditions and loops to your programs. In this task you will create a small program that uses conditions and loops to output custom messages to users.

name: Pass Task 3.3 - Circle Moving
description: In this task you will create a small program that allows the user to move a circle around on the screen.

name: Credit Task 3.4 - User Input Functions
description: So far we have provided you with a unit to read and check values entered by the user: the Terminal User Input unit. In this task you will extend this library so that it has a number of additional functions.

name: Credit Task 3.5 - Concept Map
description: A concept map visually shows the relationships between concepts. This task aims to help you think through the various relationships between the structured procedural programming concepts and the associated programming artefacts.

name: Distinction Task 3.6 - Mandelbrot
description: The Mandelbrot provides an interesting challenge in order to determine how to zoom in to and out of the section of the Mandelbrot being shown to the user.

name: Pass Task 4.1 - Using Records and Enumerations
description: Effectively organising your data makes programs much easier to develop. By using records and enumerations you can start to model the entities associated with your programs.

name: Credit Task 4.2 - Fruit Punch
description: Create a program using the concepts covered so far.

name: Credit Task 4.3 - Concept Map
description: A concept map visually shows the relationships between concepts. This task aims to help you think through the various relationships between the structured procedural programming concepts and the associated programming artefacts.

name: Test 1
description: Test 1 covers weeks 1 to 3

name: Pass Task 5.1 - Hand Execution of Arrays
description: Demonstrate how arrays work within the computer.

name: Pass Task 5.2 - Arrays of Records
description: Add an array of records to your program that uses records.

name: Credit Task 5.3 - Food Hunter
description: Extend a small game to make use of arrays.

name: Credit Task 5.4 - Concept Map
description: A concept map visually shows the relationships between concepts. This task aims to help you think through the various relationships between the structured procedural programming concepts and the associated programming artefacts.

name: Distinction Task 5.5 - Sort Visualiser
description: Create a program to demonstrate sorting working within the computer.

name: Pass Task 6.1 - Structure Charts
description: Illustrate the structure of your program using a structure chart.

name: Pass Task 7.1 - Programming Principles
description: Describe the principles of structured, procedural, programming.

name: Distinction Task 7.2 - Game of Life
description: Create the Game of Life

name: Pass Task 8.1 - Language Reference Sheet
description: Create a reference sheet for C or C#

name: Pass Task 8.2 - Circle Moving 2
description: Recreate your circle moving program using C

name: Test 2
description: Covers all core concepts.

name: Pass Task 9.1 - Reading Another Language
description: Demonstrate how programs written in C work within the computer

name: Credit Task 9.2 - Another Language
description: Create a program with C using the concepts covered.

name: High Distinction Task 10.1 - Custom Program
description: Extend your custom program to meet the High Distinction criteria.

name: High Distinction Task 10.2 - Research Report
description: Start working on a research project

name: Pass Task 11.1 - Learning Summary Report
description: Summarise your learning from the unit.

name: Distinction Task 6.2 - Custom Program
description: Start working on your custom program!
